items.title: Google proves it hasnâ€™t forgotten the original Pixel Buds Pro with new update
items.summary: The firmware update is light on details, but it confirms the OG earbuds are still being maintained.
items.body: Credit: Rita El Khoury / Android Authority TL;DR Google is rolling out firmware version 5.11 to the original Pixel Buds Pro. The update includes bug fixes, as well as performance and security improvements, with no specific details shared. Itâ€™s the first publicly acknowledged update since Google last detailed changes in October 2023. Google hasnâ€™t yet forgotten about your previous-gen earbuds and has just rolled out a new firmware update for the original Pixel Buds Pro. From what we can tell, this marks the first publicly acknowledged update for the earbuds in quite some time. According to a post on the Pixel Buds Pro Help Forum , firmware version 5.11 is now becoming available. Google says the update focuses on bug fixes, performance improvements, and security updates, but doesnâ€™t share any specific details beyond that.

items.title: Spot the fake: Can you figure out which photos were made with AI?
items.summary: It's getting harder and harder.
items.body: I published a post last year showcasing six pairs of images, challenging readers to try and figure out which ones were made with AI . Out of the six image pairs, I was surprised to learn that more than half of our readers got at least four right, with 20 percent not making a single mistake. But can this result be repeated in 2025? A lot has changed in a year, with AI generation tools making a big leap forward. Nano Banana Pro is a lot better than Imagen 4 used in my post last year, as it has the ability to create more realistic images, ditching things like super smooth skin and that perfect bokeh effect in some cases. The tool also allows me to make minor changes to specific parts of an image, which was impossible a year ago, since Gemini just created a brand new image when I asked for a change.

items.title: Hereâ€™s why I ditched ChatGPT and moved to local AI
items.summary: My local AI setup handles writing, coding, and private documents without sending data online.
items.body: I was one of the first people to jump on the ChatGPT bandwagon. The convenience of having an all-knowing research assistant available at the tap of a button has its appeal, and for a long time, I didnâ€™t care much about the ramifications of using AI. Fast forward to today, and itâ€™s a whole different world. Thereâ€™s no getting around the fact that you are feeding an immense amount of deeply personal information, from journal entries to sensitive work emails, into a black box owned by trillion-dollar corporations. What could go wrong? Now, thereâ€™s no going back from AI, but there are use cases for it where it can work as a productivity multiplier. And thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve been going down the rabbit hole of researching local AI . If youâ€™re not familiar with the concept, itâ€™s actually fairly simple. It is entirely possible to run a large language model, the brains behind a tool like ChatGPT, right off your computer or even a phone. Of course, it wonâ€™t be as capable or all-knowing as ChatGPT, but depending on your use case, it might still be effective enough. Better still, no data leaves your device, nor is there a monthly subscription fee to consider. But if youâ€™re concerned that pulling thiâ€¦

items.title: ATP announces new rules over playing in extreme heat
items.summary: The ATP introduces a new extreme heat rule from 2026 which will allow players on the men's tour to take a 10-minute cooling break during best-of-three sets singles matches.

items.title: Portuguese GP to return to F1 calendar in 2027
items.summary: Portugal will return to the F1 calendar in 2027 and 2028, with a race held at the Algarve International Circuit near Portimao.

items.title: Aiden Ross Shines With ABBA Classic in â€˜The Voiceâ€™ Season 28Â Finale
items.summary: The Monday episode featured the Top 6 finalists each performing two songs â€” one contemporary and one classic.
items.body: Aiden Ross closed out Part 1 of The Voice Season 28 finale with a stirring rendition of ABBAâ€™s â€œThe Winner Takes It All,â€ delivering one of the nightâ€™s most talked-about performances as the competition narrowed ahead of Tuesdayâ€™s live results show. The Monday (Dec. 15) episode featured the Top 6 finalists each performing two songs â€” one contemporary and one classic â€” as viewers voted overnight to determine the Season 28 winner, which will be revealed during the Dec. 16 finale broadcast. Ross, representing Team Niall, returned to the stage last with the ABBA classic, stripping the song back and leaning into its emotional core. Coach Niall Horan praised the performance in the moment, telling his finalist he was â€œso, so proudâ€ and urging America to vote following what he called an â€œabsolutely incredibleâ€ showing. Earlier in the night, Ross opened his finals run with JVKEâ€™s â€œGolden Hour,â€ earning another enthusiastic response from Horan, who said the singer consistently finds â€œthe heartbeatâ€ of every song he performs. The two performances capped a strong night for Team Niall, which also included DEK of Hearts advancing via Americaâ€™s vote. Each coach entered the finale with one artist â€¦

items.title: 2026 is already shaping up to be a bad year to buy a new smartphone
items.summary: Upcoming phones will very likely cost more and offer less value.
items.body: Credit: Ryan Haines / Android Authority TL;DR A new Counterpoint Research report predicts that smartphone prices will rise in 2026, with average selling prices increasing by as much as 6.9% as memory costs surge. The same report points to shrinking shipments and higher manufacturing costs, pushing smartphone makers to potentially cut specs like RAM and limit budget options. For consumers, this means phones launching next year will be pricier while offering fewer meaningful upgrades. If youâ€™ve been waiting patiently to upgrade your phone in 2026, hoping the next generation of devices will be faster, cheaper, or offer better value, weâ€™ve got some bad news for you. Smartphones will most likely get more expensive and less featureful in the coming year compared to what you can buy today.

items.title: This laptop is powered by your Samsung phone, and it just got a big upgrade
items.summary: You get a screen, keyboard, trackpad, battery, speakers, and ports, while your phone or device handles everything else.
items.body: Credit: NexDock TL;DR NexDock has launched its 6th-generation lapdock for $229. Itâ€™s a PC shell thatâ€™s designed to run Samsung DeX, Android desktop modes, Windows, Linux, and handheld PCs. You get a screen, keyboard, trackpad, battery, speakers, and ports, while your phone or device handles everything else. The upgraded NexDock includes a brighter 14-inch 16:10 touchscreen and a vastly improved trackpad. If the name NexDock doesnâ€™t ring a bell, we donâ€™t blame you. The company has been quietly making â€œlapdocksâ€ â€” laptop shells that turn your phone or handheld device into a full desktop â€” for nearly a decade. Now, NexDock is hoping to put itself back on the map with its 6th-generation NexDock, which is officially in stock and shipping worldwide.

items.title: Joe Ely, Pioneer of Texasâ€™ Progressive Country Sound, Dies atÂ 78
items.summary: Ely blended genres and opened for The Clash and Rolling Stones.
items.body: Texas singer/songwriter Joe Ely died Monday (Dec. 15) in Taos, New Mexico, from complications of Lewy Body Dementia, Parkinsonâ€™s disease and pneumonia, according to his spokesperson. Ely was 78. Amarillo, Texas, native Ely was raised in Lubbock, Texas, and later moved to Austin and was part of an influential wave of progressive country rock artists who helped establish Austin as a live musical capital. His music crossed lines and helped birth the Americana genre. “Joe Ely came out of West Texas like a rocket and shock the Austin City Limits stage like nobody before or since– over 10 times!,” Austin City Limits executive producer Terry Lickona told Billboard . “Joe was and will always be a superstar. In Texas, he was our Bruce Springsteen.” Ely was inducted into the Austin City Limits Hall of Fame in 2022. â€œJoe Ely performed roots music like a true believer who knew music could transport souls. His musical style could only have emerged from Texas,â€ said Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum CEO Kyle Young in a statement. â€œHis true measure came through in the dynamic intensity of his powerhouse live performances, where he could stand his ground aside feâ€¦

items.title: Ciara to Headline First TikTok Awards in theÂ U.S.
items.summary: The show will stream live from the Hollywood Palladium on Thursday.
items.body: Ciara is set to headline the first TikTok Awards in the U.S., streaming live from the Hollywood Palladium on Thursday (Dec. 18). Ciara topped the Billboard Hot 100 for seven weeks in 2005 with â€œGoodiesâ€ (featuring Petey Pablo) and reached the top spot on the Billboard 200 in 2006 with Ciara: The Evolution . She won a Grammy in 2006 as a featured artist on Missy Elliott â€™s â€œLose Control,â€ which was voted best short form music video. She is set to perform some of her greatest hits, which also include â€œOh,â€ â€œ1, 2  Step,â€ â€œGet Upâ€ and â€œLove Sex Magic.â€ Related KATSEYE, sombr, Laufey & More Vie for Breakthrough of the Year at First-Ever TikTok Awards: Nominations Announced Ciara Embraces Her New NYC Home With Times Square Flash Mob for ‘Nice n’ Sweet’ & ‘Low’: ‘New York Breeds That Kind of Energy’ (Full Video) Ciara Calls Her New Duet With Latto ‘The Type of Collaboration I Always Dreamt of’ The TikTok Awards also announced presenters of key awards: Breakthrough Artist of the Year â€“ REI AMI Okay Slay Award (Beauty) â€“ Tan France  Video of the Year â€“ Tefi Pessoa I Was Today Years Old Award (Education) â€¦

items.title: Harry Styles and Dua Lipa Make Wired Earbuds Cool Again â€“ and They Make a Great StockingÂ Stuffer
items.summary: Wired earphones offer better sound quality and are more comfortable. Plus: there's no charging required
items.body: All products and services featured are independently chosen by editors. However, Billboard may receive a commission on orders placed through its retail links, and the retailer may receive certain auditable data for accounting purposes. When did wired earbuds become cool again? From Harry Styles to Charli XCX, stars have been spotted ditching their wireless earbuds in favor of being tethered to their phones, and it seems the previously-dated look is now an instant status symbol. Model and influencer Romeo Beckham recently posted photos of himself using the wired earphones while getting ready for Fashion Week. And Dua Lipa revealed that she keeps not one, but three pairs of wired earbuds with her at all times. Now, they’ve become a great gift idea or stocking stuffer idea for the holidays too. View this post on Instagram Of course there are many reasons why wired earbuds are better than wireless ones: for starters, they’re less likely to fall out of your ears and disappear into some crack or crevice on the road, or on your commute. Many people also find them more comfortable, since they’re pretty “locked in” to your ears rather than dangling from your lâ€¦

items.title: Ray J Has â€˜No Doubtâ€™ the Kardashians Are Racketeers â€“ And Says ChatGPTÂ Agrees
items.summary: Via a new court filing in his legal battle with Kim Kardashian and Kris Jenner, the singer is creatively arguing that an AI chatbot entrenched his beliefs about them.
items.body: Ray J is doubling down on his assertion that Kim Kardashian and Kris Jenner have engaged in racketeering, saying in a new court filing that their family business empire is â€œa criminal enterprise akin to the mob.â€ The Friday (Dec. 12) filing is the latest salvo in a salacious legal battle that began with Kardashian and Jenner suing Ray J for defamation after they say he falsely talked about them being investigated for racketeering on both a TMZ broadcast and Twitch livestream. The R&B singer countersued , accusing Kardashian of intentionally leaking their infamous sex tape back in 2007. Related Kim Kardashian and Kris Jenner Leaked Infamous 2007 Sex Tape, Ray J Claims in New Lawsuit Hot 97's 'Ebro in the Morning' Show Is 'Over' After 13 Years Universal Music Group Opens UMusic Shops In New York, London Ray J (William Ray Norwood Jr.) is now asking a Los Angeles judge to throw out the defamation allegations under Californiaâ€™s anti-SLAPP law, which bars meritless litigation that tramples on free speech. The singer says the claims will fail because, at the time he went on TMZ and Twitch, he genuinely believed Kardashian and Jenner had violated the Racâ€¦

items.title: Dionne Warwick Sued by Rights Firm Over Doja Cat Sample Deal Fees: â€˜Trying to EvadeÂ Payingâ€™
items.summary: The company says it repped the R&B legend for years on tricky rights issues "at no cost to her" â€” in return for a 50 percent cut of her royalties "in perpetuity."
items.body: Dionne Warwick is facing a lawsuit claiming the legendary singer has turned her back on a rights management company that negotiated her deal for the famed sample of her song â€œWalk on Byâ€ in Doja Cat ‘s chart-topping hit â€œPaint the Town Red.â€ In a case filed Monday (Dec. 15), a company called Artists Rights Enforcement Corp. says itâ€™s repped Warwick for years â€œat great effort and expenseâ€ on tricky issues, ranging from the recent Doja sample to a 2002 lawsuit against Atlantic Records. But the company says sheâ€™s now trying to back out. Related Dionne Warwick Didn’t Know Doja Cat Sampled ‘Walk on By’ in ‘Paint the Town Red’: ‘Doja Who?’ Hot 97's 'Ebro in the Morning' Show Is 'Over' After 13 Years Universal Music Group Opens UMusic Shops In New York, London â€œAfter decades of service, Ms. Warwick is now trying to evade paying Artists Rights hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars,â€ the companyâ€™s lawyers write. â€œIn so doing, she has violated her contracts with Artists Rights.â€ Artists Rights says it provided its services to Warwick for years â€œat no cost to her,â€ assuming all the risk and upfront cosâ€¦

items.title: Most of you are fine with the Pixel 10â€™s battery life, survey shows
items.summary: Nearly two-thirds of poll respondents say the Pixel 10's battery is either average or great.
items.body: Weâ€™ve seen some unexpected battery behavior in the Pixel 10 series. Battery life is typically okay for us on Googleâ€™s latest, but depending on the workload, Pixel 10 phones sometimes offer shorter battery life than last yearâ€™s Pixel 9 series did. Stranger still, the Pixel 10 Pro XL in particular can be annoyingly inconsistent. Curious to know more, we started asking how you all feel about battery life in Pixel 10 phones beginning in October â€” and now, nearly two months on, weâ€™ve got the results of that polling. According to our poll, most readers â€” about an even third â€” report that the Pixel 10 seriesâ€™ battery life is â€œgreat,â€ with the phones lasting through an entire day, no sweat. Thatâ€™s the type of behavior youâ€™d expect out of a flagship phone thatâ€™s only a few months old, and itâ€™s good to see that itâ€™s the most common experience among our readers. Another 30 percent of respondents say battery experience has been â€œaverage.â€

items.title: The Apple TV app pulls a reverse Netflix and starts supporting Google Cast on Android
items.summary: Netflix just removed Google Cast support, and Apple is now adding the feature to its own streaming service.
items.body: TL;DR Apple launched an Apple TV app on the Google Play Store in early 2025, but it was missing a core Android streaming feature. Now, an update to the Apple TV app for Android adds Google Cast support for casting to smart TVs and displays. The Apple TV appâ€™s Google Cast implementation includes a miniplayer and full-screen UI while streaming. Apple TV is becoming a popular streaming service outside of the Apple ecosystem, with viral hits like Severance, Pluribus, and Ted Lasso. The streaming platform finally earned its own Android app in February, allowing Android users to subscribe to Apple TV or the MLS Season Pass on their smartphone via Google Play Billing. While the Android app supported many of the same features as its iOS counterpart, it was missing one thing: Google Cast support. Now, thatâ€™s changing, with version 2.2 of the Apple TV app for Android adding Google Cast support. Itâ€™s rolling out now on the Google Play Store , making it easy for users to cast Apple TV shows to their favorite smart TVs and displays. Thereâ€™s a persistent Cast button beside the Apple TV account bubble on the appâ€™s homepage. A quick tap reveals Google Cast displays nearby, including any Nest Hubsâ€¦

items.summary: In a big win for winter warriors, Google Maps has resurrected its lost ski trails and lifts feature.
items.body: Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority TL;DR Google Maps has brought back ski trails, lodges, and lifts after previously removing them in 2024. The return of this feature includes updated data from new imagery and ski resort map information. The feature supports several resorts, but is also missing a few. In the past, skiers and snowboarders could turn to Google Maps to check on ski trails, lifts, and lodges. It was a handy tool that helped many plan their winter trips. However, this feature disappeared from the Maps app in 2024. Now Google has brought it back just in time for your next ski run. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Google may soon make your AI Mode history even easier to access
items.summary: Getting ready to shine the spotlight on AI Mode history.
items.body: TL;DR Google appears to be considering a change to how you access AI Mode history. Right now, the Google app hides your history behind the AI Mode button, but it could soon replace Labs in the upper-left. The Google app on iOS has already made this adjustment. Google never forgets. At least, not if you have history turned on in your My Google Activity settings. And for most of us, thatâ€™s a good thing, helping us pick up dropped trains of thought or just reminding us about content we enjoyed. How you access those records depends on what kind of history youâ€™re looking for, and right now Google appears to be working on an easier new way to check out your AI Mode history in particular. items.title: Google will let you tell Discover what you want to see
items.summary: Are we tired of talking to apps yet?
items.body: TL;DR A new Google Search Labs experiment lets you â€œTailor your feed,â€ personalizing Discover content. The experiment sees users make plain-language requests about the type of content they want to see. You can sign up for the latest experiment in Search Labs now. Google gives the option to try a bunch of developing search-related features early in Search Labs. This weekend, a Reddit user spotted a new Labs feature that purportedly lets you tweak the content on your Discover feed to your liking â€” using AI, of course. User Gaiden206 posted screenshots of the new experiment on the r/pixel_phones subreddit. Called â€œTailor your feed,â€ the experiment lets you tell the Google app specifically the type of content you do or donâ€™t want to see in Discover, with flexibility to add or remove topics, or narrow the focus of a type of content youâ€™re already seeing. You can even use it to have Discover pick up or exclude content from specific sources.

items.title: Google Search has a subtle new way to push you toward AI Mode
items.summary: Pretty sneaky, Google.
items.body: TL;DR Google Search has added a new plus (+) icon in the search bar. The button allows you to upload documents and images, doing which will open AI Mode. The UI doesnâ€™t clearly explain what the button is supposed to do. Google really wants people to try its AI Mode, which turns searching for information on the web into a quasi-conversation with a multimodal chatbot. Just last week, we saw that Chrome is getting ready to incorporate AI Mode right into the browser , and now, a new icon that surfaces some AI Mode functionality is showing up on the Google homepage. The search bar at google.com has included an AI Mode icon on the right hand side for some time. Today, weâ€™re seeing an additional plus icon at the left side of the bar. Clicking the plus brings up options to upload an image or document, either of which will initiate an AI Mode interaction where you can ask questions about your upload.

items.title: Hereâ€™s why you may want to think twice before using airport Wi-Fi
items.summary: New data shows mobile networks often far outperform airport Wi-Fi, with one carrier leading the way.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Ookla data shows Verizon delivered the fastest mobile download speeds at many major US airports. Mobile networks in general were usually faster than airport Wi-Fi, and twice as fast on average. Wi-Fi still prevailed at a few locations, but most airports havenâ€™t yet adopted the more recent Wi-Fi standards. As airports brace for the holiday travel rush, a new report suggests that your mobile carrier may make a big difference when it comes to the last-minute downloads at the airport. According to new data, Verizon consistently delivers faster mobile download speeds at airports than its competitors, usually also far surpassing the speed of the airport Wi-Fi itself. The report from Ookla , which analyzed Speedtest data from the first half of 2025, found that Big Red delivered the fastest median download speeds at many major US airports. The report compared airport Wi-Fi performance with AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon across the 50 busiest airports in the country, looking specifically at median download speeds.

items.title: Googleâ€™s killing off its dark web report because users didnâ€™t know what to do with it
items.summary: Dark web reports will be gone for good in just two months.
items.body: TL;DR Google has let you scan the dark web for personal information revealed in breaches. That service is going away in early 2026. Google stops scanning for new data on January 15, and deletes all old report data on February 16. When security experts warn you to not reuse the same passwords over and over, and to frequently change the ones you are using, theyâ€™re not just considering some theoretical risk. Data breaches frequently expose our private information to hackers, and all too often that info gets passed around on the dark web, ready to be exploited. A couple years back, Google introduced dark web reports to let us know what personal details might be floating around out there â€” and now theyâ€™re about to go away. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: A simple trick to avoid T-Mobileâ€™s T-Life app just stopped working
items.summary: Even cash transactions now appear to go through the app.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR T-Mobile has added cash payments to its T-Life app, closing a loophole that let in-store customers avoid using it. The workaround gained attention after employees and customers shared tips about paying cash to bypass T-Life. With cash now routed through the app, all standard in-store transactions appear to follow the same T-Life process. Like it or not, T-Mobile is determined to ensure the T-Life app is the hub for all customer activity . The latest move in this regard appears to be the company closing a loophole that allowed in-store customers to sidestep its app. Until recently, paying with cash meant transactions could still be handled through older in-store systems rather than the app, but that no longer seems to be the case. According to reporting from PhoneArena , T-Mobile has now added cash payments directly into T-Life, meaning those transactions are also routed through the app. The change was highlighted in a Reddit post and subsequently confirmed to the publication by a T-Mobile employee, suggesting the update is already live in stores.

items.title: Spotify is down â€” itâ€™s not just you having streaming problems
items.summary: Social media lit up with complaints as widespread Spotify outage rolls on.
items.body: TL;DR Spotify is currently down for many users. Issues started earlier this morning, and the company has since acknowledged them. Spotify appears to have server problems, and even its status page is returning errors. Having trouble concentrating this morning but canâ€™t quite put your finger on whatâ€™s wrong? Does the world just seem a little quieter than it used to? Youâ€™re not imagining things, as a widespread Spotify outage appears to be seriously impacting availability of the music streaming service. You know that the situation is bad when a companyâ€™s own status page is itself generating an error message, as is the case with Spotifyâ€™s right now. Over on Reddit , threads going back about an hour now describe users being unable to access Spotify streams, and on X Spotify confirmed at 8:45a ET that it was â€œaware of some issues right now and â€¦ checking them out.â€

items.title: Could this massive handheld with a 7-inch 144Hz OLED be the next budget champion?
items.summary: There aren't many Android gaming handhelds this big, and this one will surely undercut the competition.
items.body: TL;DR The budget-focused handheld maker MANGMI has revealed its next device, called the Pocket Max. It features a massive 7-inch 144Hz OLED panel, plus full-size sticks and front-facing speakers. Benchmark leaks suggest it may feature a Snapdragon 865, which would help keep costs lower than other large handhelds. Android gaming handhelds have had a huge year, with devices of all shapes and sizes more affordable than ever. One standout hit was the PSP-focused MANGMI AIR X , which blew us away for less than $100. The company has just teased its second handheld release, and so far, itâ€™s looking like another winner. Called the MANGMI Pocket Max, it lives up to its name with a massive 7-inch 144Hz OLED panel. That alone puts it in rarified territory, since only a handful of Android gaming handhelds can match that size. The AYN Odin 2 Portal, AYANEO Pocket EVO, and Razer Edge are the only true OLED alternatives, but theyâ€™re all expensive, costing anywhere from $400 to $800 for the best experience.

items.title: One UI 8.5 is largely a hit, but a survey reveals many of you arenâ€™t happy with this one key aspect
items.summary: It turns out liking the update doesnâ€™t mean liking everything about it.
items.body: One UI 8.5 (left) and iOS 26 Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority Samsungâ€™s One UI has always proudly sported its own personality. Itâ€™s obviously Android, but it has also long looked and felt distinctly â€œSamsung,â€ even as other Android skins borrowed ideas from all over the place. With the One UI 8.5 beta now in the wild, though, that identity is starting to feel like itâ€™s up for debate. In a recent opinion piece , my colleague Joe Maring said One UI 8.5 might be the update where Samsung finally went a step too far. He highlighted changes like the new Quick Settings layout and refreshed Samsung apps, which can be tweaked to look a lot like iOS 26â€™s Control Center and navigation bars. The update adds useful customization and isnâ€™t short on polish, but Joeâ€™s bigger point was questioning the point at which refinement starts to feel more like imitation. That question is what led us to ask our readers how they feel about One UI 8.5â€™s iOS-like changes.

items.title: iRobot just filed for bankruptcy: Hereâ€™s what happens to your Roomba now
items.summary: iRobot promises to keep the app and devices working, at least until the new owners take over entirely.
items.body: Credit: Jonathan Feist / Android Authority TL;DR Popular robot vacuum Roombaâ€™s maker, iRobot, has filed for bankruptcy. iRobotâ€™s business will transition to a new owner, which is also its primary manufacturer. The company has shown signs of distress since its acquisition by Amazon failed to secure the EUâ€™s approval in early 2024. Roomba has, over the past decades, become the colloquial term for household robot vacuums. Despite its success, the company behind the product lineup is facing an economic downturn. Roombaâ€™s seller, iRobot, recently announced (via The Verge ) that it has filed for bankruptcy in the District of Delaware. However, iRobot is using Chapter 11 terms, which means that the business is likely to continue to exist rather than being liquidated to pay back its debtors. Instead, iRobot will transfer 100% of the business ownership to its primary manufacturers, Shenzhen PICEA Robotics Co. Ltd. and Santrum Hong Kong Co. Ltd., who will hold the rights collectively under the name Picea.

items.title: Verizonâ€™s free line offer returns, but it falls short of T-Mobile
items.summary: Verizon's free line is only for 36 months, unlike its rival's more generous terms.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Verizon is offering a free â€œUnlimited Welcomeâ€ line for 36 months to customers on specific Unlimited plans who check the â€œoffersâ€ section of the app. The promotion is strictly Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) and requires in-store activation, paperless billing, and autopay. Rival T-Mobileâ€™s free line promo does not come with an expiry date, making it a much better deal. T-Mobileâ€™s free line promo is the most well-known promo in the industry, but other carriers also offer free lines from time to time, although they tend to fall short. Verizon is back again with a free line promo, and hereâ€™s how you can take advantage of it. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Google Maps in Gemini just got way smarter at finding your next favorite spot
items.summary: Google's Gemini now shows maps, photos, and reviews first to help you decide faster.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR Gemini now puts Google Maps first in local searches, replacing long text replies with an instant visual overview. Generic red dots are replaced by emoji-style pins and detailed cards featuring photos, star ratings, and review highlights. The visual overhaul is currently rolling out to English users on both the mobile and desktop versions of Gemini. Googleâ€™s Gemini app just got a big update for anything related to location, and itâ€™s making it easier to find places that matter to you. Now, instead of a plain text list with a small map at the bottom, your local search results start with visuals and context inside Gemini . If youâ€™ve ever asked Gemini, â€œWhereâ€™s a good coffee spot nearby?â€ and had to scroll through lots of text before opening Google Maps , this update aims to fix that. Now, the first thing you see is a map, followed by cards for each place with photos, star ratings, and highlights from reviews, the Gemini team confirmed on X . Android Authority first spotted this feature earlier this month, along with a ChatGPT-inspired redesign to Geminiâ€™s tool menu .

items.title: Surprise! Galaxy Watch 4 starts getting One UI 8 Watch, likely its last update
items.summary: It's a pretty good send-off for a smartwatch that helped kick off Samsung's Wear OS comeback.
items.body: Credit: Jimmy Westenberg / Android Authority TL;DR Samsung is now rolling out One UI 8 Watch to the Galaxy Watch 4. The update carries build numbers R87OXXU1JYK4/R870OXM1JYK4. This is likely the last major OS update for the Watch 4, which launched in 2021. Samsung has started rolling out the One UI 8 Watch update for the Galaxy Watch 4 , marking what is very likely the smartwatchâ€™s last major OS upgrade.

items.title: 7 features from other phones I want to see on Googleâ€™s Pixels
items.summary: I love my Pixel, but these features would make it even better.
items.body: Compared to the barebones Nexus phones of Googleâ€™s past, the Pixel series has a lot of great features that make using a Google phone unlike any other smartphone. Whether itâ€™s Call Screening or Now Playing, thereâ€™s a lot to love about the Pixel experience , and Iâ€™m glad that I returned to it after a long break. But as much as I love my Pixel 10 Pro , there are things Iâ€™d like Google to borrow from other manufacturers. From Apple to OnePlus, these are the seven things I want to become a part of the Pixel. Better volume control

items.title: Gemini could soon stop wasting your time on basic questions, and thatâ€™s great news
items.summary: By letting you skip deep thinking and switching to a faster Flash model.
items.body: Credit: Mishaal Rahman / Android Authority TL;DR Google is testing a new feature that lets users prevent Gemini 3 Pro from thinking. This will allow Gemini to fall back on the Flash model, resulting in quicker responses. Google is already testing the feature with a select set of users. With the release of the Gemini 3 generation of AI models , Googleâ€™s smart assistant has racked up brilliant deep-thinking capabilities. However, the lack of a smart automatic model selector actively switching between fast and deep-thinking models â€” as ChatGPT offers â€” can result in Gemini taking longer and consuming more tokens for straightforward queries that donâ€™t truly require deep thinking. An upcoming update to Gemini, however, could fix that, allowing users to manually override thinking and dial back to a quicker response.

items.title: Spotify may finally let you tone down those distracting animations (APK teardown)
items.summary: A new in-app toggle could help you reduce animations independent of your system settings.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Spotify currently relies on global system settings to control its in-app animations, but these settings affect all animations on the phone. New code found in the Spotify app suggests a specific â€œReduce animationsâ€ toggle is coming to the app. This feature could help users with motion sensitivity or those who simply find the autoplaying visuals too distracting. Spotify gives users plenty of reasons to switch over to its service . Features like Spotify Wrapped set up the whole year-in-recap trend, while the service has also been leaning into AI to help curate your next playlist . These additions have come at a steady pace, but the app also needs a cleanup â€” or at least, an option to disable some of the distractions. Spotify could be looking to tone down the experience by allowing users to disable animations in the app. NEWSLETTER | Authority Insights --> Authority Insights You're reading an Authority Insights story. Subscribe to our new Authority Insights newsletter for more exclusive reports, app teardowns, leaks, and in-depth tech coverage you won't find anywhere else. sign up now By signing up, you agree to our Terms of Use and acâ€¦

items.title: Unexplained iOS 26 photo bug is leaving some Android users red-faced
items.summary: And Apple has no fix for it yet.
items.body: Credit: Ryan Haines / Android Authority TL;DR iPhone users have discovered an odd bug that is turning older photos taken on Android phones red. While the issue remains unexplained, some people point to possible HDR format incompatibility. While iOS 26.2 doesnâ€™t fix it, some folks have also figured out a fix Apple has long attempted to keep Android and related services out of reach for its users . That friction inadvertently impacts users switching from an Android device to an iPhone or using both OSes at the same time. Now, it appears iOS bugs may also lean into those biases. Several iPhone users noticed an unexplained iOS 26 bug that changes the colors of pictures taken on Android devices and shared with them. Numerous reports on Reddit say that their pictures, when viewed in the iOS Photos app, turn red when they zoom in on the image. The same does not occur while viewing the images on a device running iOS 18.

items.title: Google starts rolling out a new way to use NotebookLM
items.summary: Directly within Gemini.
items.body: Credit: Stephen Schenck / Android Authority TL;DR NotebookLM is starting to appear inside Gemini, letting users attach notebooks directly to their chats for added context. The integration seems to be rolling out in a very limited way. It allows you to use Geminiâ€™s latest reasoning models while still being able to jump back to NotebookLM when needed. To say NotebookLM is one of the most powerful and useful AI tools Google has introduced is an understatement. Now, Google is simplifying access to the tool by integrating it directly into Gemini.

items.title: Waze may be finally catching up to Google Maps with this highly-requested feature
items.summary: Traffic Lights support is finally showing signs of life as testing reportedly beings in one country.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Waze seems to have started testing support for traffic lights on its navigation maps. The feature is reportedly being tested only in one country for now. Waze users have been wanting the traffic light support for years, and the company confirmed in May that it is indeed a planned feature. After years of user requests, Waze seems to be finally testing support for traffic lights on its navigation maps. Itâ€™s a small but meaningful update for the crowdsourced navigation app that has long focused on real-time driving conditions, and one that Google Maps has already offered since 2022.

items.title: 6 design misses stopping Gemini from catching up to ChatGPT
items.summary: What's holding back Gemini is Gemini itself.
items.body: Gemini comes with a major update that breaks the internet , everybody jumps on it to check it out, and after a day or two of hype, everybody goes back to using ChatGPT. The familiarity with ChatGPT trumps all the innovation Google has been making, but thereâ€™s another reason why Gemini still trails. The Gemini app simply isnâ€™t as inviting as ChatGPTâ€™s, which has been around longer and has a better way with people. Google is already working on a big redesign for the Gemini app, and I have a wish list for what it needs to get right.

items.title: Iâ€™m using Samsungâ€™s One UI 8.5 beta, and thereâ€™s one feature every Android skin needs to copy
items.summary: This is how Android's Quick Settings should be.
items.body: If youâ€™re a Samsung fan, you probably heard about the One UI 8.5 beta release last week. Samsung officially launched the beta on December 8, and since then, weâ€™ve discovered a surprising number of new features and settings. While thereâ€™s a lot to like about One UI 8.5, having used the update myself for a few days, itâ€™s clear to me which new feature is the best. And I wonâ€™t beat around the bush â€” itâ€™s Samsungâ€™s new Quick Settings .

items.title: Google Messages has a major problem, and Iâ€™m sick of it
items.summary: You're getting there, Google, but you have some work to do.
items.body: Iâ€™m tired of Google Messages on the web. Tired of constantly having to re-verify my credentials. Tired of not being able to send a voice message. Tired of a watered-down version of what has turned into quite a beautiful messaging application on Android phones. In a world where iMessage , WhatsApp , Signal , Telegram , and so many other incredible options exist, itâ€™s time for Google to expand its recently improved messaging efforts beyond the smartphone. Messaging matters on other devices, too

items.title: Android 16 QPR2 has breathed new life into my Google Pixel 9 Pro
items.summary: With every Android 16 update, I notice that my Pixel 9 Pro XL gets even more interesting.
items.body: When I got my Pixel 10 Pro XL, I thought I would never look again at my â€œolderâ€ Pixel 9 Pro XL. I realize how privileged and braggy this sounds, but itâ€™s the reality of my job: New Pixel lands at my desk, ergo last yearâ€™s Pixel, which I was perfectly happy with until two seconds earlier, instantly feels antiquated. But this hasnâ€™t been the case this year, and the reason is Android 16. Specifically, all the major updates to Android 16 that have appeared on my Pixel 9 Pro XL, with the most recent one being the Android 16 QPR2 update . More elaborate Material 3 Expressive

items.title: This cheap Android clamshell let me relive the Nintendo DS glory days, and it felt like coming home
items.summary: The closest Iâ€™ve gotten to reliving the DS era without dusting off my original hardware.
items.body: Iâ€™m just going to come out and say it: The Nintendo DS is one of the greatest consoles of all time. The combination of a unique form factor and an absolutely killer library of games made it an absolute staple of my teen years. And now, thereâ€™s a modern, authentic, and affordable handheld that recreates it. And no, itâ€™s not the AYN Thor. While AYNâ€™s take on the 3DS is undoubtedly a great device, the 3DS came out when I was a broke college student, so it doesnâ€™t trigger the same level of nostalgia. It also starts at $300, which is expensive for a still-broke working adult with two children.

items.title: This one feature fixed the worst part of using Android and Apple together
items.summary: A rare Apple-Android truce that actually helps.
items.body: There are lots of perks to sticking to a single ecosystem. You get cross-platform sharing and connected features that are so convenient you donâ€™t even want to break out of that bubble. A big reason for that is simple: removing even one piece from the equation feels so jarring that you instantly want to jump back into the ecosystemâ€™s cozy arms. And thatâ€™s exactly what companies bank on to keep you buying more of their products. But sticking to one ecosystem isnâ€™t practical for everyone â€” it certainly isnâ€™t for me. Covering tech means I have to stay in touch with everything on the market, from Android and Windows to iPhone and Fire TV. And I live by it, too. My main computer is a MacBook, I shuffle between an iPhone and a Pixel 10 , and my smart home setup runs on Google Home speakers along with Google TV sticks and TVs. And thatâ€™s just me. Some of my family members use an iPhone with a Windows laptop, while others have an Android phone.

items.title: Android 17 could mimic this helpful iOS feature to reduce motion sickness
items.summary: Android 17 may add support for Motion Assist, a feature that helps reduce motion sickness while youâ€™re in a moving vehicle.
items.body: Many people avoid using their Android phones in moving vehicles due to motion sickness, a condition that can induce nausea, headaches, and dizziness. Motion sickness is believed to be caused by a sensory conflict; your eyes focus on a stationary object (the phone) while your inner ears signal that you are moving. Since people spend so much time as passengers, itâ€™s a bummer that many canâ€™t use their phones without feeling sick. Fortunately, Google is working on a new feature for Android 17 aimed at reducing this discomfort. Youâ€™re reading the Authority Insights Newsletter , a weekly newsletter that reveals some new facet of Android that hasnâ€™t been reported on anywhere else. If youâ€™re looking for the latest scoops, the hottest leaks, and breaking news on Googleâ€™s Android operating system and other mobile tech topics, then weâ€™ve got you covered.

items.title: The Samsung Galaxy S26 is already the worst phone of 2026
items.summary: This level of stagnation is unforgivable.
items.body: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Nx5OLMak2s The more we hear about the upcoming Galaxy S26 series, the more underwhelming this launch feels. For a second there, Samsung had all of us fooled with dreams of a refreshed line-up consisting of a new Galaxy S26 Pro, an Edge, and an Ultra, which wouldâ€™ve been a nice departure from its traditional S, S Plus, and S Ultra plans. Then, the Galaxy S26 Pro was unceremoniously killed before it was even launched ( not that it seemed that exciting to begin with ), and the rumors converged back to the same olâ€™ brand new Galaxy S26, S26 Plus, and S26 Ultra. This internal confusion and identity crisis at Samsung has left the company scrambling for last-minute plans, and it shows. Every leak weâ€™ve heard so far points to the Galaxy S26 Ultra being a semi-decent upgrade to the S25 Ultra, since it was always part of the companyâ€™s plans, but the S26 and S26 Plus are practically repackaged and unchanged from their S25 counterparts. This is why I donâ€™t need to wait for 2026 to be over before claiming what I already know: The Galaxy S26 and S26 Plus will be the worst phones of 2026.

items.body: Credit: Ryan Haines / Android Authority Considering that Google and Apple are fierce rivals, most people are surprised to learn that Pixels and iPhones are actually made by the same company. While it may seem weird, itâ€™s actually common practice in the world of not only smartphones but electronics in general. But who is this mysterious company behind your favorite smartphone, why do both Apple and Google use it, and which other companies are also on its client list?

items.title: I take an Android tablet everywhere I go: These are the best ones you should buy
items.summary: The Android tablet race is tighter than ever, and that's good news for you (and me).
items.body: I didnâ€™t consider myself a tablet person for a very long time. Sure, I briefly tried to use one to replace my laptop in college, but I quickly learned that it wasnâ€™t quite a like-for-like trade. So, back to the shelf it went, waiting for the day I just wanted a larger form factor for entertainment. And, for a while, I ignored the scaled-up side of Android altogether. Now, though, things are different. Android tablets are better than ever, and they come in all shapes and sizes, ranging from just larger than a foldable phone to nearly rivaling full-sized laptops. Iâ€™m still not sure how many of them I would trust as laptop replacements, but Iâ€™ve found that they fill so many more niches than they used to. Here are the best Android tablets that I think you should actually spend your money on.

items.title: This beast of a Google TV projector might be a real threat to your living room TV
items.summary: The easiest big-screen upgrade Iâ€™ve tested, and possibly the most persuasive.
items.body: My TV should probably be nervous. Iâ€™ve spent years insisting I donâ€™t need anything bigger, brighter, or more dramatic in my living room, mostly to keep myself from rearranging the layout for the sixth time. But the moment I fired up the Dangbei DBOX02 Pro and watched it casually splash a massive, laser-lit 4K image across my wall, that confidence wavered. From setup to screen size, this $999 Google TV-powered projector delivers a brighter, bigger, and far more effortless viewing experience than a TV at the same price. Suddenly, a flat screen feels less like a staple and more like a convenience Iâ€™ve been overvaluing out of habit. If a projector can make me rethink furniture arrangements, budget priorities, and the long-term viability of my current HDMI cable drawer, itâ€™s worth talking about.

items.title: Google is ruining the best thing about the Pixel Watch
items.summary: What good are fast updates that miss out on new features?
items.body: This past week, Google upgraded its Pixel Watch wearables to Wear OS 6.1 . The update brings Android 16 QPR2 to watches for the first time, and more importantly, includes some cool new features. The highest-profile addition is new gesture controls that let you pinch your fingers or flick your wrist to perform certain actions with one hand, a useful option that competitors like Samsung and Apple have offered variations of for some time in their own wearables. Thereâ€™s just one problem. These gesture controls are exclusive to the latest Pixel Watch 4 , with no immediate plans from Google to bring them to older models. And if you ask me, that feels pretty un-Pixely.

Now both tools are starting to appear for Gemini users, supporting editing as well as analysis. Google has already given us lots of great tools for working with imagery, and a couple months back we spotted evidence of development on another big one: Letting you mark up images you share with the Gemini app . items.title: Android could soon track your medical symptoms in Health Connect
items.summary: Google is preparing major upgrades to Health Connect for a future Android release. Hereâ€™s what to expect.
items.body: TL;DR Google is redesigning Health Connectâ€™s settings to place connected apps front and center while streamlining the overall menu layout. A new grouped view for â€œApp accessâ€ will allow you to grant or deny permissions for entire data categories with a single tap. We also found evidence that Health Connect will soon support tracking for alcohol consumption and various medical symptoms. Android has dozens of fitness tracking tools , giving you a wealth of options for improving your health. Managing the data collected by these apps can be tough, however, which is why Google created Health Connect . This service aggregates all your health and fitness data in one central, secure place. It also simplifies sharing between apps, meaning developers donâ€™t have to build their own data transfer tools. When Google launched Health Connect in 2022, it supported just over 40 data types across six categories. With the release of Android 16 , Google expanded the service to include yoga and meditation sessions (â€œWellnessâ€) as well as medical records like allergies, vaccinations, and lab results. Most recently, the Android 16 QPR2 update brought native step tracking support to Health Connect.

items.title: Google starts testing Androidâ€™s new DND-overriding call option
items.summary: Get ready for everyone's "urgent" call, as Call Reason beta access begins.
items.body: TL;DR Last month we spotted Google developing Call Reason, a system for signaling call priority that could override DND. Google formally announced Call Reason at the start of December, saying that beta access would get underway shortly. Testers have now begun to start getting access to Expressive Calling and Call Reason. Do Not Disturb is one of the most useful features our phones have, and often feels like the last line of defense against a world that wants us constantly assailed by notifications. But sometimes someone really, really needs to get in touch with us, so itâ€™s good to know that we have options there, whether thatâ€™s designating contacts who can override DND, or recognizing repeat callers by their urgency. With the arrival of QPR2 earlier this month, Google announced another way it was giving us an option to punch through DND â€” and thatâ€™s finally starting to arrive now. With Gemini enhancing a wide range of modern Google apps , thereâ€™s no reason the classic favorites should stay behind. This is why Google is now announcing new improvements based on Gemini to one of its headlining apps, Translate. Google has today announced new upgrades to Translate, powered by enhanced Gemini models. Google doesnâ€™t specify which newer models, but we believe it is referring to the recently announced Gemini 3 and 3 Pro . With this improvement, Translate (and related functionality in Search) will be able to offer more nuanced, natural translations of slang, idioms, and other complex figures of speech.

items.title: Google is finally fixing the most annoying thing about wireless ADB
items.summary: Tired of frequent disconnections when using wireless ADB? A future Android release has the solution.
items.body: TL;DR Android is getting a quality-of-life update that automatically turns on wireless debugging when connected to trusted Wi-Fi networks. Currently, the feature automatically turns off after a period of inactivity, forcing users to constantly manually re-enable it. The new behavior is live in the latest Android Canary builds, though a stable release might not happen until Android 16 QPR3 or Android 17. One of the most powerful tools at an Android developerâ€™s disposal is the Android Debug Bridge ( ADB ). This command-line tool lets you control your Android device from a PC, allowing you to quickly push new apps, view system logs, and much more. Itâ€™s also essential for tinkerers and enthusiasts looking to remove bloatware or access hidden features, explaining why so many non-developers also install it. While developers and enthusiasts may use ADB for different reasons, they agree on one thing: using it wirelessly sucks. Fortunately, Google is rolling out a small update to wireless ADB that should make it much less annoying. items.title: This free Android app made me love reading again, one sentence at a time

items.body: Iâ€™ll be the first to admit that I donâ€™t have the same attention span I once had, and that has directly impacted my reading habit . Doomscrolling short-form videos on social media and a writerâ€™s job that requires me to stare at walls of text (and write them too) have made me incapable of finishing a book. Iâ€™ve long considered it a shame, as once upon a time, I could read and finish an entire Harry Potter book in a day. But now, I can barely cross a few pages before losing my concentration and floating away. If you find yourself in a similar situation of being unable to read through a book anymore, hereâ€™s a new app that could help you bring back your reading habit, one sentence at a time. items.title: Blame AI: Phone specs could go backward in 2026
items.summary: As the RAM crisis worsens, phone makers could have no choice but to offer lesser RAM at higher prices.
items.body: Credit: Robert Triggs / Android Authority TL;DR Due to soaring RAM prices, smartphones in 2026 are expected to be more expensive while featuring less RAM than 2025 models. High-end 16GB RAM models may nearly disappear, and 12GB and 8GB models could see massive reductions in availability as makers revert to 8GB and 4GB RAM, respectively. Phone makers are caught between pricing pressures and reduced availability of consumer-grade DRAM as RAM manufacturers prioritize HBM supply for enterprise customers. 2026 isnâ€™t shaping up to be a good year to buy a new phone, or any new tech in general. Weâ€™ve heard reports that phones are about to become more expensive due to RAM inflation . Now, new reports suggest that phone specs could actually start going backwards because of RAM inflation. items.title: Broke your Galaxy Z TriFold display? Hereâ€™s how much youâ€™ll pay (itâ€™s a lot)
items.summary: You should think twice about buying the Galaxy Z TriFold if you're worried about repair costs.
items.body: Credit: Paul Jones / Android Authority TL;DR It reportedly costs as much as ~$1,243 to fix the Samsung Galaxy Z TriFoldâ€™s folding screen in Korea. This repair fee is on par with the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultraâ€™s launch price in the region. The Samsung Galaxy Z TriFold is the companyâ€™s first dual-folding foldable phone , offering a massive 10-inch display in your pocket. We already know that foldable phone repair costs can be pricey, but you might want to brace yourself if you damage the TriFoldâ€™s screen. Tipster yeux1122 reports on their blog that it costs 1.657 million or 1.834 million won (~$1,123 or ~$1,243) to fix the Galaxy Z TriFoldâ€™s folding display. Meanwhile, repairing the cover display will set you back 137,000 or 226,000 won (~$93 or ~$153).

items.title: AT&Tâ€™s new security system is a Google Nest bundle with a cellular lifeline
items.summary: AT&Tâ€™s new Connected Life system brings Google-powered smarts and outage-proof backup.
items.body: Credit: Stephen Schenck / Android Authority TL;DR AT&T has unveiled Connected Life, a new security system built around Google Nest devices and Abodeâ€™s professional monitoring. The system stays online during outages thanks to cellular backup and a battery-powered hub. You purchase the equipment upfront (starting at $399), and the kits are designed for DIY installation. AT&T is taking another big swing at the smart home, and this time it isnâ€™t going in alone. After shutting down its Digital Life platform in 2022, the carrier is back with a new security and automation system built on Googleâ€™s smart-home ecosystem and Abodeâ€™s professional monitoring. The company has announced Connected Life, and the idea is straightforward: you get a home security system that keeps working even if your Wi-Fi goes out or the power fails. AT&T includes cellular backup and a battery-powered hub, so the system stays on during outages.

items.title: Leak reveals how AirTag 2 could outpace Android trackers again
items.summary: With the U2 chip, enhanced precision finding and detailed battery report, Apple looks ready to regain its lead over rivals.
items.body: Credit: Rita El Khoury / Android Authority TL;DR Leaks suggest Apple will improve pairing, precision finding, battery details, and motion tracking with the upcoming AirTag 2, widening the gap against Android trackers. Some new features could also arrive on current-gen AirTags via a software update. Initial plans for a release in 2024 have reportedly slipped to early 2026. Appleâ€™s AirTag had long remained competition-free, but Android trackers finally caught up â€¦ almost. While Android trackers have improved enough to compete with the AirTag, the AirTag has long been awaiting an upgrade that would let it regain its lead. For the AirTag 2, Apple was rumored to upgrade to the second-generation Ultra-Wideband chip (U2) for extended range, and now, more potential upgrades have leaked. Donâ€™t want to miss the best from Android Authority ?

items.title: Prepare your wallets: Galaxy S26 Ultraâ€™s biggest upgrade is all but confirmed
items.summary: It's looking more likely that the S26 Ultra will bring a long-overdue wired charging upgrade.
items.body: Credit: Joe Maring / Android Authority TL;DR The Samsung Galaxy S26 Ultra has been listed on a Chinese regulatory website. The listing reveals satellite connectivity and 60W wired charging speeds. This adds more fuel to rumors that the phone will have faster wired charging. Samsung is expected to launch the Galaxy S26 series in the next couple of months, and leaks continue to trickle in ahead of the mooted release window. Now, a Galaxy S26 Ultra listing has corroborated reports of faster charging. Twitter user @ZionsAnvin spotted a Galaxy S26 Ultra certification listing on Chinaâ€™s 3C regulatory website. We were also able to find this listing, which confirms the SM-S948 model number and 60W wired charging (20V/3A). Check out our screenshot below.

items.title: Forget raw power, this is what I want from the Pixel 11â€™s Tensor G6
items.summary: One of the Pixel's best features is too annoying to use, and Tensor could fix that
items.body: Googleâ€™s move from Qualcomm processors to its own Tensor chips in the Pixel series has been a contentious one. Tensor G5 in the Pixel 10 series is a far stronger chip than its predecessors, but many users still bemoan the difference in performance compared to the latest Snapdragon . As we start to look ahead to next year, I, too, want to see an improvement made to the Pixel 11 and Tensor G6, but not the one most of you are thinking about. Itâ€™s hard to love one of the Pixelâ€™s best camera features

items.title: We went hands-on with the Galaxy Z TriFold. Hereâ€™s the good (and the bad)
items.summary: We've used the Galaxy Z TriFold, and we have thoughts.
items.body: Ever since Samsung announced the Galaxy Z TriFold last week, weâ€™ve had a lot of questions about the phone. What does it feel like to use Samsungâ€™s first tri-fold foldable? Are the hinges sturdy? How heavy/bulky is the phone? Is this folding design better or worse than the Huawei Mate XT? Well, we now have answers to all of those. My colleague Paul Jones recently went hands-on with the Galaxy Z TriFold at the Dubai Mall â€” one of the only places in the world where Samsung is demoing the phone â€” and he came away with a lot of thoughts about Samsungâ€™s futuristic foldable.

items.title: Pixel 9 Pro Fold is finally getting a camera feature it should have had from the start
items.summary: And it lets you make better use of the inner screen.
items.body: Credit: Rita El Khoury / Android Authority TL;DR Google is bringing a key Pixel 10 Pro Fold feature to the older Pixel 9 Pro Fold. In the Camera app, you can now use half of the screen to view recently captured images. The option has been available on the Pixel 10 Pro Fold since launch. I find foldables to be the ultimate productivity boosters . Not only does the extra real estate on the inner screen allow more content to be viewed at once, which can be helpful for reading, but it also serves what would typically require two screens. Even more so, foldables offer a special benefit for photography. You can fold them mid-way and prop them up on a flat surface, engage the external screen for a preview, and use the rear cameras for selfies. Even when youâ€™re looking at the inner screen, you can use half of the screen as a viewfinder for the camera and the other half to review shots you just took. Many foldables, including the wide range of Galaxy Z Folds , Vivo X Folds , and even the OnePlus Open , already support the feature. Meanwhile, Google only added it to its foldable lineup recently with the Pixel 10 Pro Fold , and the feature has been exclusive to it since launch. Thankfully, tâ€¦

items.title: Tried and tested: The most frequent tech gifts Iâ€™ve given over the years
items.summary: No one has complained so far.
items.body: Credit: C. Scott Brown / Android Authority Christmas is only a few weeks away, and itâ€™s time for me to start planning what to get the important people in my life. And Iâ€™ll be honest, itâ€™s a challenge â€” especially since I generally hate shopping for others, or just shopping in general. To make this part of the year easier for me, I have a list of tech products I regularly gift to people. These are products that just about anyone would be happy to get, ranging from about $10 to $110. I want to share this list with you today, just in case youâ€™re running out of ideas for what Christmas present to give to the tech lover (or really, anyone) in your family.

items.title: Meet JMGOâ€™s newest, delightfully compact, ultra-short-throw laser projector
items.summary: This tiny ultra-short-throw still delivers a 100-inch image from inches away.
items.body: TL;DR JMGO has launched the JMGO O3, a compact and affordable ultra-short-throw (UST) laser projector. The unit is just 250 Ã— 219 Ã— 107mm and 2.4kg, far smaller than the O2S Ultra. It is currently priced at CNY 3,749 (~USD $530) and is limited to China. JMGO has expanded its projector lineup once again, this time with the JMGO O3, a compact ultra-short-throw (UST) laser model designed to deliver big-screen entertainment in smaller spaces. The projector quietly launched in China earlier this month and is already drawing attention, and not only thanks to its unusually low price for a laser-based UST. What really sets the projector apart is just how compact it is. At only 250 Ã— 219 Ã— 107mm and about 2.4kg, itâ€™s dramatically smaller than JMGOâ€™s own O2S Ultra, which nearly doubles it in both footprint and weight. That tiny profile makes its performance even more impressive: the JMGO O3 can throw a 100-inch image from just 22cm off the wall thanks to a 0.18:1 throw ratio. In practice, you get a cinema-sized picture in spaces where bulkier UST units might not fit, making it suitable for tight apartments, bedrooms, dorm rooms, or secondary media setups.

items.title: Seeing â€˜giantâ€™ emojis in Gboard? Hereâ€™s the reason why
items.summary: Nothing is wrong with your eyes, it's a tiny change Gboard recently made.
items.body: Credit: Edgar Cervantes / Android Authority TL;DR Gboardâ€™s emoji grid has quietly shifted from nine columns to eight, making the emojis look bigger. Users who spotted the change couldnâ€™t figure out what exactly happened. It turns out that Google added a flag in October that allows it to adjust the emoji column counts in Gboard, and itâ€™s now set to eight. If your Gboard emojis have felt oddly large lately, youâ€™re not alone. Thereâ€™s a good reason why those emojis are suddenly looking bigger.

items.title: Googleâ€™s making a silly and annoying change to how you uninstall system app updates
items.summary: Encountered a bug or unwelcome change in a system app? It's now a little harder to uninstall the offending update.
items.body: Credit: Hadlee Simons / Android Authority TL;DR Google has removed the ability to uninstall updates for system apps via the Play Store. Users now have to visit app settings in the settings menu to uninstall system app updates. This is a more convoluted way of uninstalling updates to system apps. Google has long allowed Android users to uninstall updates for system apps via the Play Store . Unfortunately, the company has now removed this Play Store feature for no clear reason. NEWSLETTER | Authority Insights --> Authority Insights You're reading an Authority Insights story. Subscribe to our new Authority Insights newsletter for more exclusive reports, app teardowns, leaks, and in-depth tech coverage you won't find anywhere else. sign up now By signing up, you agree to our Terms of Use and acknowledge the data practices in our Privacy Policy. You may unsubscribe at any time. We can confirm that system app listings in the Google Play Store no longer have an uninstall button, which is used to uninstall app updates. Instead, these app listings only offer an open button. The change seems to be widespread and doesnâ€™t target a specific Play Store app version. Weâ€™re seeing this change on dâ€¦

items.title: Google Account settings are too complicated. Hereâ€™s how Google plans to fix it
items.summary: Spoiler: By throwing an AI chatbot at the problem.
items.body: Credit: Andy Walker / Android Authority TL;DR Google is testing an AI chatbot interface to help you navigate through your account settings. We discovered a chat-based interface, powered by Gemini, that could help you find specific settings items or change specific settings. The feature is currently under development, but we were able to pull some strings to show you how the chat interface could look. The ultimate objective Google foresees for Gemini is to help you with basic and mundane tasks on your phone. One of them is helping you navigate menu items better through a conversational interface. Google Home recently added a feature that lets you â€œAsk Homeâ€ about things such as objects or people in your security camera feed. Soon, it may bring a similar chat-based interface to help you navigate through the maze of settings related to your Google account . items.title: Surprise: Samsung has a new camera sensor for its next flagships after all
items.summary: Shutter lag has been the Achilles Heel of Samsung's Ultra phones, but the firm's next camera sensor could fix this.
items.body: Credit: Ryan Haines / Android Authority TL;DR Samsung is reportedly working on a new smartphone camera sensor with global shutter-like capabilities. This should result in better image quality when taking photos of fast-moving subjects. Itâ€™s believed that this 12MP sensor could land on a next-generation flagship Galaxy smartphone. Virtually all smartphone cameras on the market use a rolling shutter to capture photos, but Samsung may have developed a new camera sensor that has â€œglobal shutter-levelâ€ capabilities. Sisa Journal (h/t: Jukan on X) reports that Samsung has developed a smartphone camera sensor with global shutter-like capabilities. Itâ€™s believed that this tech could come to its next-generation Galaxy flagships. Itâ€™s unclear if the outlet is referring to the Galaxy S26 series , the Galaxy S27 family , or upcoming foldables.

items.title: A second screen for selfies? This iPhone case is something Android makers should steal
items.summary: The clever new case adds a tiny rear display and extra storage to the iPhone 17 Pro, and we need this for Android phones now!
items.body: Credit: SelfixCase TL;DR This smartphone case features a second display for selfie previews, allowing users to take selfies using the primary camera of their phone. Itâ€™s only designed for the iPhone 17 Pro, but the concept is cool enough to be adapted for Android phones as well. It also features a built-in slot for a 2TB microSD card, allowing users to expand their phoneâ€™s storage. If you read Android Authority regularly, you know weâ€™re obsessed with our phone cases . We love talking about innovative cases, even if theyâ€™re not necessarily Android phone cases, like this one. A company called Dockcase has made a phone case that comes with an unusual advantage â€” a secondary display for selfie previews. Called the Selfix case (h/t GSMArena ), itâ€™s designed specifically for the iPhone 17 Pro, though we donâ€™t see why something like this canâ€™t be built for an Android phone.

items.title: WHO expert groupâ€™s new analysis reaffirms there is no link between vaccines and autism
items.summary: New analysis from a WHO global expert committee on vaccine safety has found that, based on available evidence, no causal link exists between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD). The conclusion reaffirms WHOâ€™s position that childhood vaccines do not cause autism.

items.title: WHO issues global guideline on the use of GLP-1 medicines in treating obesity
items.summary: To address the growing global health challenge of obesity, which affects more than 1 billion people, WHO has released its first guideline on the use of Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 (GLP-1) therapies for treating obesity as a chronic, relapsing disease.

items.title: Measles deaths down 88% since 2000, but cases surge

items.title: Lifetime toll: 840 million women faced partner or sexual violence
items.summary: Violence against women remains one of the worldâ€™s most persistent and under-addressed human rights crises, with very little progress in two decades, according to a landmark report released today by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UN partners. Nearly 1 in 3 women â€“ estimated 840 million globâ€¦

items.title: More countries report rising levels of drug-resistant gonorrhoea, warns WHO
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that gonorrhoea, a sexually transmitted infection, is becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics, according to new data from its Enhanced Gonococcal Antimicrobial Surveillance Programme (EGASP), which monitors the spread of drug-resistant gonorrhoea. Thâ€¦

items.title: 'It felt like God's hand on my brain' - the day England were humbled by teenager
items.summary: BBC Sport's From The Ashes series concludes with the inside story of Ashton Agar's record-breaking introduction to Test cricket as a 19-year-old batting at number 11.

items.title: World marks cervical cancer elimination day as countries accelerate action
items.summary: Today marks the first World Cervical Cancer Elimination Day â€“ mandated by the World Health Assembly â€“ a historic milestone in global efforts to end a preventable cancer.

items.title: WHO promotes lifesaving intervention for small and preterm babies on first official World Prematurity Day
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is marking its first official observance of World Prematurity Day with the launch of a new global clinical practice guide for Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) â€“ a simple, proven and life-saving intervention that significantly improves survival for preterm and low birthâ€¦

items.title: WHO and Brazil urge swift action on BelÃ©m Health Action Plan at COP30
items.summary: The COP30 Special report on health and climate change: delivering the BelÃ©m Health Action Plan, notes that rising temperatures and collapsing health systems are claiming more lives, and calls for immediate and coordinated action to protect health in a rapidly warming world. It follows the launch ofâ€¦

items.title: WHO launches global guidelines on diabetes during pregnancy on World Diabetes Day
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) today released its first global guidelines for the management of diabetes during pregnancy, a condition affecting about one in six pregnancies â€“ or 21 million women annually. The new recommendations provide a critical roadmap to tackle this growing health challenâ€¦

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

items.title: Global gains in tuberculosis response endangered by funding challenges
items.summary: Tuberculosis (TB) remains one of the worldâ€™s deadliest infectious killers, claiming over 1.2 million lives and affecting an estimated 10.7 million people last year, according to the WHO Global Tuberculosis Report 2025, released today.

items.title: Egypt becomes the seventh country in the Eastern Mediterranean Region to eliminate trachoma as a public health problem
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) today announced that Egypt has successfully eliminated trachoma as a public health problem, marking a historic public health milestone for the country and WHOâ€™s Eastern Mediterranean Region (WHO EMR). It is the seventh country in WHO EMR to achieve this milestoneâ€¦

items.title: Countries make progress on WHO Pandemic Agreement annex on pathogen access and benefit sharing system
items.summary: In an important step, Member States started discussing for the first time the proposed draft text of the annex to the WHO Pandemic Agreement that establishes the Pathogen Access and Benefit Sharing (PABS) system. The PABS system is a key part of the global agreement adopted earlier in 2025 to make â€¦

items.title: Fifth meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the upsurge of mpox 2024
items.summary: Concurring with the advice and considerations expressed by the Committee during the meeting, the WHO Director-General, on 5 September 2025, determined that the upsurge of mpox 2024 no longer constitutes a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).

items.title: WHO issues guidance to address drastic global health financing cuts
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) today released new guidance for countries on ways to counter the immediate and long-term effects of sudden and severe cuts to external funding, which are disrupting the delivery of essential health services in many countries. The new guidance, called â€œResponding â€¦

items.title: WHO calls for a new era of strategic urban health action with global guide to unlock healthy, prosperous and resilient societies
items.summary: With the new guide for decision-makers launched today, WHO provides concrete ideas to usher in a new era of urban health action. The Guide responds to the growing demand for integrated solutions that address health challenges and promote health more broadly in urban settings.

items.title: Climate inaction is claiming millions of lives every year, warns new Lancet Countdown report
items.summary: WHO and global partners are calling for the protection of peopleâ€™s health to be recognized as the most powerful driver of climate action, as a new global report released today warns that continued overreliance on fossil fuels and failure to adapt to a heating world are already having a devastating â€¦

items.title: Fiji becomes the 26th country to eliminate trachoma as a public health problem
items.summary: In a landmark public health achievement, Fiji has been validated by the World Health Organization (WHO) for eliminating trachoma as a public health problem. Trachoma, a neglected tropical disease (NTD) and the worldâ€™s leading infectious cause of blindness, no longer poses a public health threat in â€¦
